PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The City of Poway has taken a pro-active approach to emergency responses and safety at the Water Treatment Plant.  The annual emergency response drills are documented and mitigation measures to improve the Team's response are continuously being reviewed. City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant has implemented all recommendations from the initial technical studies, as well as all recommendations from the latest Process Hazard Analysis and Hazard Review Revalidations (April 6, 2022). The recommendations from the PSM/RMP/CalARP Compliance Audits (May 22, 2020) are completed. 

The Process Safety Management team is planning to complete several items over the next year as their continued efforts to provide a safe work environment for the City employees.  These changes include the following items:

1.	Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2.	Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3.	Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4.	Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.

City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant has established a mechanical integrity program for maintaining and operating the chlorine and aqueous ammonia equipment and uses the Chlorine Manual from the Chlorine Institute as a basis.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An investigation into the facility's accident history during the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study conducted on September 10, 2018, revealed that in the last five years (April 2017 - April 2022), there have been no releases of chlorine that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 10 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material. However, the site has reported minor incidents or near misses which warranted internal incident investigation. Each incident was investigated and detailed accounts are recorded within incident investigation forms maintained at the facility. In each release scenario, less than 1 pound of chlorine was released and there were no injuries resulting from any of the incidents. 


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

If a release of chlorine or aqueous ammonia were to occur, the City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant's response plan is to call 911 in order to reach the Fire Department's HAZMAT team.  Employees will evacuate the facility to a point that is upwind of the hazard.  Evacuation drills are performed annually.  The emergency response plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS - CHLORINE AND AQUEOUS AMMONIA

The chorine system at the City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the Uniform Mechanical Code, Uniform Building Code, and the Uniform Fire Code.  All of these codes serve to reduce risk within the facility by specifying acceptable design criteria for the chorine system and on-site buildings. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant's senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but also maintains a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The Utility Systems Supervisor administers the City's safety and environmental policies. The Utility Systems Supervisor is responsible for various inspections of the City's facilities to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs.  These programs include hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The facility has been in operation since 1973 but the water treatment system was modified in 1997 and the aqueous ammonia system was added in late 2002.  The process is located at 14521 Lake Poway Road, Poway, CA 92064.  

The chlorine system for the City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant consists one-ton chlorine containers which are the storage vessels.  Chlorine gas is pulled from the one ton containers to the chlorinators through the vacuum regulator.  The chlorinators are equipped with water at the injectors and the resulting chlorine solution is distributed through rotameters to other water processes at the facility. 

Below provides a list of the chlorine equipment.

Chlorine One-Ton Containers (9) in the Storage Area
Vacuum Regulators (4) in the Storage Area
Chlorinators (3) in the Chlorinator Room (Chemical Building)
Injectors (3) in the Chlorinator Room (Chemical Building)
Scrubber System, Located at the south end of the facility.

The maximum quantity of chlorine that can be stored on site is 18,000 pounds.
